Occasion Will Be President s
Second Appearance Before
Student Body
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of
the Johns Hopkins University will be
the principal speaker at the semi-annual spring tap day of Beta Chapter of
Omicron Delta Kappa, national honorary activities fraternity next Thursday. This will be Dr. Bowman's second appearance before the student
body, the first occasion being at the
last ODK initiation in January, when
Dr. Bowman himself was inducted.
The subject of Dr. Bowman's address will be "Student Activities" and
will be of utmost interest to the members of the undergraduate body, since
it will be the first time that Dr Bowman has spoken to the students in regard to his plans for the University.
During the course of his address, he
will discuss the Student Council; Omicron Delta Kappa; Student Activities
Council; Changes in the Undergraduate Curriculum as specified in the
1936-1937 catalogue; Student Movements; Undergraduate Organizations.
especially one which is to be organized, and which Dr. Bowman calls
"The New Student Activity".

This is what gave the School of
Higher Studies its distinctive place
in American education when The
Johns Hopkins University was founded in 1876. The combination of teaching and research that had proved so
successful in the Academic Division
of the University also became one
of the guiding principles of the School
of Medicine from its beginning. It is
a principle that permeates all of our
schools. It is the heart of the University idea. In an atmosphere of this
sort, the College has special and great
opportunities. That is why I said in
my Commemoration Day address, "we
affirm our resolute intention to advance the interests, improve the quality, and bring to a high state of efficiency, the Johns Hopkins College of
Arts and Sciences." Let me repeat
that there is no difference of opinion
among either the Trustees or the faculty on this point.

Finding just one more excuse for a
convivial evening together, "old grads"
will congregate in the new gymnasium
at Homewood Field next Tuesday evening, May 12, to drink beer, renew
acquaintance and enjoy an exhibition
of fencing, boxing and wrestling.
By way of combining business with
pleasure, chairmen of all alumni solicitation groups are to meet at eight
o'clock, a little in advance of the
festivities, which are scheduled for
eighty-thirty, to make a formal report of campaign pledges received up
to that time. Professor J. Trueman
Thompson, Alumni Committee chairman, has issued a blanket invitation
to every alumnus to swell the crowd

In a program lasting till 9:05 p. m., the work of the Johns Hopkins will
be explained to radio listeners by three prominent Hopkins men:
At 7:50, Dr. George Boas, professor of the History of Philosophy,
will discuss the general program of the College of Arts and Sciences and of the Graduate School. At 8:20 and 8:50, respectively,
Stephen Rushmore, M.D. '02, now of the Harvard Medical Faculty,
and James F. Norris, Ph.D., '95, of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will speak on the University's significance in medical education and the sciences.

The Undergraduate Committee of
the Johns Hopkins University Funds
Campaign entered its third week last
Monday with an anounced subscription of $1,247.50 from more than thirty
student contributors. Clarence J.
Weimer, chairman of the committee,
also expressed satisfaction at the
succes of appeals to the parents of
undergraduates.

General Committee Seeks

Individuals
Reporting the sum of $229,347 in
pledges now to their credit, 550 undergraduates, alumni, faculty, and
friends of the Hopkins yesterday began the second week of their campaign
for $750,000. Plans to canvass actively
about 8,000 prospective givers in the
Baltimore
area
are
progressing
rapidly, committee chairmen reported_
Particular progress was indicated in
the General Committee, which at pres
ent combines the largest number of
active workers with the smallest number of assigned prospects. More
than 200 men in the business and
professional community, under the
chairmanship of President Bowman,
have volunteered to carry the Universtiy's appeal to 1700 firms and individuals in town.
The three major divisions of the
committee, the business, citizens and
professional groups, are headed respectively by Daniel Willard and Carlyle Barton, both of the Board of
Trustees, and Dr. Dean Lewis, of the
School of Medicine. The principle of
organization in each ease has been
that of having a number of team captains, each in turn supported by as
many solicitors as the number of assigned prospects requires.

Daniel Coit Gilman spent twelve
months searching the world for men
of calibre great enough in their specific fields of knowledge to carry on the
proposed work of the University. The

Hopkins has always fought to keep
alive the memory of the historic results of that search. Today it is
not only the honor and privilege, but
the obligation as well ,of the entire
world, and more particularly of the
friends of the Hopkins, to aid in the
perpetuation of the name which the
men Gilman found made for the University.

wishes go with it.
* * *
Please accept the enclosed check,
as my contribution to the coming
drive.
Michael Pupin, the non-Hopkins inventor, said in one of his books, that
no rich man should die without leaving money to Hopkins.
He is reported to have said, later,
that no rich man should wait till he
died, without doing so.
It would seem that Baltimore should
show how much she owes to Hopkins
a an example to the out of town possible contributors.
The alumni, especially, should do
their bit, and then some.
With best wishes for a successful
drive.

While I am in sincere sympathy
wan your effort to raise funds for
the Johns Hopkins University, it is
a matter of deep regret that I can
pledge only $25.00 for 1936. For the
sake of my son, who is an enthusiastic
and loyal supporter of the University,
and the many young men who are
struggling to secure an education, I
wish you success and hope that the
campaign will bring returns far in
excess of your fondest hopes.

From The
President
(Continued from Page 1, Col. 4)
The greatest asset of a university
is not its portfolio of securities, its
athletic prowess, its campus, or its
buildings; but rather its men, the
spirit in which they work, and the
standards of quality and achievement
which they maintain. A noble building
is an inspiring symbol only when it
houses creative intellects or the products-'of such intellects. Otherwise,
it is a monument to folly and waste.
The beauty of a campus irradiates
the memories of students as a cherished experience only as they associate that beauty with vistas opened
one day by inspiring personalities,
with riddles of life deciphered, or with
epoch-making disclosures in science.

The only machine
of its kind
500 camshafts can be inspected
every hour by an automatic
machine which has been designed
and built by the Ford Motor
Company. It is the only one of
its kind. It has a gaging accuracy
of one ten-thousandth of an inch.
It gages Ford camshafts at 25
points. Any dimension not within
the specified limits causes electrical and mechanical devices to
reject the camshaft as it leaves
the machine.
There are ten inspection stations. The camshafts are places
in registered position in carriers
mounted on an endless linked
conveyor and carried into the
machine. At each station the
conveyor stops momentarily. Automatic centers engage the ends
of the camshafts and hold them
rigidly. Then 25 floating gage

FORD
Starts Sweet
Smokes Sweet
Stays Sweet

Contributors A Message

heads lower automatically, measure the shafts, then rise. As the
conveyor moves the shafts to the
next station, other mechanism
rotates and indexes them for the
next set of gage heads.
The gage heads contain hardalloy-tipped measuring plungers
which are linked to amplifying
levers. Variations in shaft sizes,
beyond set limits, close a set of
contact points which operate two
solenoids. One sets the rejection
mechanism; the other raises a
marking plunger which puts a
daub of copper sulphate solution
on the shaft where the dimension
is over or under size.
When shafts come out of
machine they are automatically
passed or rejected. All told,
there are 54 inspections on every
Ford V- 8 camshaft.

S. P. E.'s Win

Herbert Siegel, veteran of three
year's standing, was unanimously
elected captain of the 1936-37 basketball squad, at a meeting of the lettermen last Thursday. At the same
time Stanley Prager and Mickey McDaniels were chosen co-managers for
the next campaign.
Siegel, a junior in the college of
Arts and Sciences, has been playing
varsity ball since his freshman days.
During the past two years, he has
been the Jays' most point-getter and
his all-around play has been of such
caliber as to warrant his selection
this year on the second All State
Collegiate Team.
A steady player, cool at all times,
and possessing the prerequisite court
generalship, Herb promises to be a
fine captain.

Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of
the Johns Hopkins University will be
the principal speaker at the semi-annual spring tap day of Beta Chapter of
Omicron Delta Kappa, national honorary activities fraternity next Thursday. This will be Dr. Bowman's second appearance before the student
body, the first occasion being at the
last ODK initiation in January, when
Dr. Bowman himself was inducted.
The subject of Dr. Bowman's address will be "Student Activities" and
will be of utmost interest to the members of the undergraduate body, since
it will be the first time that Dr Bowman has spoken to the students in regard to his plans for the University.
During the course of his address, he
will discuss the Student Council; Omicron Delta Kappa; Student Activities
Council; Changes in the Undergraduate Curriculum as specified in the
1936-1937 catalogue; Student Movements; Undergraduate Organizations.

Reporting the sum of $229,347 in
pledges now to their credit, 550 undergraduates, alumni, faculty, and

area
are
progressing

Particular progress was indicated in
the General Committee, which at pres
ent combines the largest number of
active workers with the smallest number of assigned prospects. More
than 200 men in the business and
professional community, under the
chairmanship of President Bowman,
have volunteered to carry the Universtiy's appeal to 1700 firms and individuals in town.

committee, the business, citizens and
professional groups, are headed respectively by Daniel Willard and Carlyle Barton, both of the Board of

School of Medicine. The principle of
organization in each ease has been

Daniel Coit Gilman spent twelve
months searching the world for men
of calibre great enough in their specific fields of knowledge to carry on the

Hopkins has always fought to keep

The greatest asset of a university
is not its portfolio of securities, its
athletic prowess, its campus, or its
buildings; but rather its men, the
spirit in which they work, and the
standards of quality and achievement
which they maintain. A noble building
is an inspiring symbol only when it
houses creative intellects or the products-'of such intellects. Otherwise,
it is a monument to folly and waste.
The beauty of a campus irradiates
the memories of students as a cherished experience only as they associate that beauty with vistas opened
one day by inspiring personalities,
with riddles of life deciphered, or with
epoch-making disclosures in science.

The only machine
of its kind
500 camshafts can be inspected
every hour by an automatic
machine which has been designed
and built by the Ford Motor
Company. It is the only one of
its kind. It has a gaging accuracy
of one ten-thousandth of an inch.
It gages Ford camshafts at 25
points. Any dimension not within
the specified limits causes electrical and mechanical devices to
reject the camshaft as it leaves
the machine.
There are ten inspection stations. The camshafts are places
in registered position in carriers
mounted on an endless linked
conveyor and carried into the
machine. At each station the
conveyor stops momentarily. Automatic centers engage the ends
of the camshafts and hold them
rigidly. Then 25 floating gage

FORD
Starts Sweet
Smokes Sweet
Stays Sweet

Contributors A Message

heads lower automatically, measure the shafts, then rise. As the
conveyor moves the shafts to the
next station, other mechanism
rotates and indexes them for the
next set of gage heads.
The gage heads contain hardalloy-tipped measuring plungers
which are linked to amplifying
levers. Variations in shaft sizes,
beyond set limits, close a set of
contact points which operate two
solenoids. One sets the rejection
mechanism; the other raises a
marking plunger which puts a
daub of copper sulphate solution
on the shaft where the dimension
is over or under size.
When shafts come out of
machine they are automatically
passed or rejected. All told,
there are 54 inspections on every
Ford V- 8 camshaft.

time of Shakespeare. While at the
Library Dr. McManaway plans to
publish articles on Shakespeare and
his times.

The Division A has turned into
somewhat of a walk-away for O.K.O.
and Tau Alpha Phi. Tau Alpha's
latest victory was scored against Beta
Theta Phi by a top heavy score of
18 6. In the lime-light for the Tau
Alphas were Windsor and Amey.
By recently scoring two victories,
the Phi Eps pulled out of last place in
Division B. This double triumph was
posted over the Pi Lambs and Phi
Sigma Deltas . The final score was
5-4. In the victory over the Pi

—the curing and ageing of leaf tobacco,
that's what's going on.
Thousands of hogsheads of mild ripe
tobacco are under these roofs...just lying
here ageing and sweetening and mellowing for Chesterfield cigarettes.
Like Rip Van Winkle, they sleep—the
tobaccos getting mellower and milder
for the cigarette that Satisfies.

Sigma Phi Epsilon continued their
winning ways with a 14-2 shellacking
of the Phi Alphas. This triumph along
with the Pi Lambs' defeat left the S.
P. E. as the sole claimant to the
Division B title. Erck, Sause, Rhode
and Bambill proved to be the big
guns for the leaders.
As was the case in basketball, an
all star team will engage a similar
team from the University of Maryland. It has also been stated by Ruben Baer that the fraternity champions will play the non-frat winners

S. P. E.'s Win

Herbert Siegel, veteran of three
year's standing, was unanimously
elected captain of the 1936-37 basketball squad, at a meeting of the lettermen last Thursday. At the same
time Stanley Prager and Mickey McDaniels were chosen co-managers for
the next campaign.
Siegel, a junior in the college of
Arts and Sciences, has been playing
varsity ball since his freshman days.
During the past two years, he has
been the Jays' most point-getter and
his all-around play has been of such
caliber as to warrant his selection
this year on the second All State
Collegiate Team.
A steady player, cool at all times,
and possessing the prerequisite court
generalship, Herb promises to be a
fine captain.
